bestBHT.bht: The people's demand for a sign from heaven aimed to challenge Jesus and his teachings, anticipating an extraordinary display of divine power. However, their request stemmed from their unwillingness to believe without divine confirmation. Jesus, recognizing their true intentions, rejected their demand and pointed to the sign of Jonah instead, indicating a denial of their desire for a sensational miracle. This interaction reveals their lack of faith and unwavering opposition to Jesus.

Henry Alford: No distinction can be drawn, as Greswell has done, for the purpose of maintaining that the two incidents were distinct, between 'a sign' and 'a sign from heaven.'"
Our Lord answers the demand in both places by the same reply, the sign of Jonas.
The ordinary Jewish idea attached to a sign would imply from heaven.
John Calvin: There can be no doubt that they ask a sign, in order to plead, as a plausible pretense for their unbelief, that Christ’s calling has not been duly attested.

They do not express such submissiveness as to be prepared to yield to two or three miracles, and still less to be satisfied with a single miracle; but as I hinted a little before, they apologize for not believing the Gospel on this pretense, that Christ shows no sign of it from heaven.

The meaning therefore is: 'Since thou professest to be a teacher and Master, if thou desirest that we should be thy disciples, let God declare from heaven that He is the Author of thy teaching, and let Him confirm thy calling by a miracle.'
Philip Schaff: Matthew places this at a later point in the narrative, and with more exactness."
Both the accusation and demand were made at the same interview.
Archibald T. Robertson: By 'sign' (σημειον) they meant a great spectacular display of heavenly power such as they expected the Messiah to give and such as the devil suggested to Jesus on the pinnacle of the temple.
These 'others' (ετερο) apparently realized the futility of the charge of being in league with Beelzebub.
Sought (εζητουν). Imperfect active, kept on seeking.
John Gill: And others tempting him,.... Others of the Scribes and Pharisees, or Sadducees: sought of him a sign from heaven;

bhtAttempts.bht: The people in this verse are demanding a sign from heaven, expecting a grand display of power like what they believed the Messiah should give. They were looking for a way to discredit Jesus and his teachings, but they were also hesitant to outright accuse him of being in league with the devil. Their continuous seeking of a sign shows that they were not open to believing in Jesus without some sort of divine confirmation from heaven. However, Jesus responds to their demand by referring to the sign of Jonah, indicating that he would not give them the miraculous sign they desired. This interaction highlights the stubbornness and lack of faith in the hearts of those who were opposing Jesus.

The people demanded a sign from heaven to discredit Jesus and his teachings. They sought a grand display of power that aligned with their expectations of the Messiah. However, Jesus saw through their motives and knew they were not open to believing without some divine confirmation. He responded by referring to the sign of Jonah, indicating that he would not provide the miraculous sign they desired. This interaction exposes their lack of faith and stubbornness in opposing Jesus.

The people, seeking a sign from heaven, intended to challenge Jesus and his teachings, expecting a remarkable display of power that the Messiah, in their view, should manifest. However, their demand was rooted in their refusal to believe without some kind of divine endorsement. Yet, Jesus discerned their true intentions and understood that they were not genuinely open to faith. Instead of complying with their request, he pointed to the sign of Jonah, signaling that he would not satisfy their desire for a sensational miracle. In this exchange, their lack of faith and unwavering opposition to Jesus is clearly revealed.

The people's demand for a sign from heaven aimed to challenge Jesus and his teachings, anticipating an extraordinary display of divine power. However, their request stemmed from their unwillingness to believe without divine confirmation. Jesus, recognizing their true intentions, rejected their demand and pointed to the sign of Jonah instead, indicating a denial of their desire for a sensational miracle. This interaction reveals their lack of faith and unwavering opposition to Jesus.

The people's demand for a sign from heaven was motivated by their desire to challenge Jesus and question the authenticity of his teachings. They expected a grand display of divine power, similar to what they envisioned the Messiah would perform. However, this demand was rooted in their refusal to believe without some form of heavenly confirmation. Jesus, perceiving their motives, dismissed their request and instead presented the sign of Jonah as a rebuttal, declining their wish for a sensational miracle. This exchange attests to their lack of faith and unwavering opposition towards Jesus.
